text:
Thanks for the tips some of you provided. Just to follow up, I found a
workaround that works and wanted to let others know. A registry addition will
keep a “target version” of your choice in place. What is nice about this is
that it both prevents Windows 11 and also interrupts an “in process” upgrade to
Windows 11 that is waiting for a restart (my case). You don’t have to complete
the Windows 11 install and then remove it. More importantly, if I can believe
many posts I read, even if you let the upgrade complete and then roll back,
Windows will continue pushing the Windows 11 download and no longer offer the
“stay on windows 10” option. It will be a constant battle just waiting for the
user to restart and again install Windows 11. 
My thinking here is that Version 22H2 of Win 10 is “supposed” to be the
last one so making that a permanent target version is not a bad thing. The user
with the issue was on this release. In any event, the registry addition can
easily be modified to a different target version. The added values can also be
deleted to allow the normal upgrade process to resume if you later decide you
are ready for Windows 11. Here’s the mod: 
---with updates paused---- 
Open Regedit 
HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\WindowsUpdate (A note: I found that
the key “WindowsUpdate” did not exist on my system so I created it. I don’t
know if Microsoft removed that key in the last year because it used to be
there). 
-add new Dword 32 bit value named TargetReleaseVersion and set its value to 1 
-add new string value named TargetReleaseVersionInfo and set its value to 22H2 
(or whatever release you want to remain in place) 
---restart----, unpause updates and you will see any needed WINDOWS 10
updates download and install. The half-installed Windows 11 is gone. You can
optionally clear the SoftwareDistribution folder if you want. I did not. 
I also noticed after this that the Windows Update page in Settings now indicates
that a target release was set by the administrator. I believe Group Policies
can also be used but this was quick and successful. 
Hopes this helps. 
Ira
%24d9e8c480%248dba4d80%24%40verizon.net

metadata.email_text_original:
Windows 11 upgrade 
Thanks for the tips some of you provided.  Just to follow up, I found a
workaround that works and wanted to let others know.  A registry addition will
keep a “target version” of your choice in place.  What is nice about this is
that it both prevents Windows 11 and also interrupts an “in process” upgrade to
Windows 11 that is waiting for a restart (my case).  You don’t have to complete
the Windows 11 install and then remove it.  More importantly, if I can believe
many posts I read, even if you let the upgrade complete and then roll back,
Windows will continue pushing the Windows 11 download and no longer offer the
“stay on windows 10” option.  It will be a constant battle just waiting for the
user to restart and again install Windows 11. 
My thinking here is that Version 22H2 of Win 10 is “supposed” to be the
last one so making that a permanent target version is not a bad thing.  The user
with the issue was on this release.  In any event, the registry addition can
easily be modified to a different target version.  The added values can also be
deleted to allow the normal upgrade process to resume if you later decide you
are ready for Windows 11.  Here’s the mod: 
---with updates paused---- 
Open Regedit 
HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\WindowsUpdate    (A note:  I found that
the key “WindowsUpdate” did not exist on my system so I created it.  I don’t
know if Microsoft removed that key in the last year because it used to be
there). 
-add new Dword 32 bit value named   TargetReleaseVersion and set its value to 1 
-add new string value named TargetReleaseVersionInfo and set its value to 22H2  
(or whatever release you want to remain in place) 
---restart----, unpause updates and you will see any needed WINDOWS 10
updates download and install.  The half-installed Windows 11 is gone.  You can
optionally clear the SoftwareDistribution folder if you want.  I did not. 
I also noticed after this that the Windows Update page in Settings now indicates
that a target release was set by the administrator.  I believe Group Policies
can also be used but this was quick and successful. 
Hopes this helps. 
Ira
Link: https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/patchmanagement/01e101da07b0%24d9e8c480%248dba4d80%24%40verizon.net
metadata.subject: RE: [patchmanagement] Windows 11 upgrade
metadata.noun_chunks: ['a workaround', 'a registry addition', 'the Windows 11 download', 'the normal upgrade process']
metadata.keywords: ['add new dword 32 bit value name targetreleaseversion', 'add new string value name targetreleaseversioninfo', 'update paused ---- open regedit hklm', 'need windows 10 update download']
